message_text: Identify 2 highlights from the readings. These could be quotes, ideas, or things you learned that resonated with you.One quote that stuck out to me was from page 163, chapter 8: "Asking participants to comment on expectations gives the instructor a process check, a means by which to determine whether or not everyone is beginning this journey from approximately the same starting point." This procedure of collaboratively determining the course goals is important not only for student buy-in, but also for the instructor's growth in the subject matter. The check-in with students about their expectations about what they are learning is important for the instructor to stay up-to-date on what knowledge is relevant in the real world, especially in classes geared towards adults who have practical experience of their own, and in subjects where the research and content is still evolving. Another quote that jumped out at me was from page 167, chapter 8: "The process of connecting the learning gained from everyday life to the learning of the course not only creates a deeper sense of meaning for the participants but it validates them as people who possess knowledge and who can apply what they know in other contexts."I happened to be reading another book recently that had a similar discussion. It was talking about how learners who automatically or deliberately connect what they are learning to things they already know tend to have a lot greater success in using and retaining their new knowledge. The challenge is that many learners don't do this automatically, but they will if asked. I wish that this learning about learning was something that was an automatic part of every class at every level of education, because it is so useful for life-long learning.  What is 1 connection/disconnection among the readings?I thought there was a strong connection between both chapter 8 and 9 and our previous discussion of communities of practice. Particularly the skill of providing substantial feedback (chapter 8 around page 176-179) jumped out to me as incredibly important for a community of practice to have value for its members. Considering our former class topics and readings, what is 1 connection/disconnection to CI 5323 overall?This course has been very deliberate in its self-reflective aspect, since we are reading about online communities while actively participating in them. Instructor deliberately asked those "expansive questions" to get us to think about how the suggestion from the text are/are not enacted in our online community, including both broadly thinking about the course, and reflecting on our own roles within the course. So the course is very "meta" in a way :-) What is 1 question or puzzle that you still have regarding the readings?I found chapter 8 to be a very practical discussion because collaboration is important for the workplace as well as in online learning communities. A question that popped into my head around page 170 is : What skills/roles/similarities exist between the online facilitator and a supervisor/manager in a professional setting? You could also ask what are the similarities between learners and employees in terms of collaboration. My workplace has had its share of challenges regarding collaboration, and I felt many of the suggestions in chapter 8 were relevant not only to our community here, but also to my workplace.

Hi T, The book is "Telling Ain't Training" by Stolovich and Keeps, and I really recommend it! Even though it's technically about "training", it has a lot of interesting ideas for teaching in general and is written in a very friendly, easy-to-understand style. There is a really interesting section on metacognition and how you can recognize it and cultivate it in your students. I think there are a lot of connections between chapter 8 and professional environments, but one that pops into my head right now is the importance of good feedback. At least for myself, it's more motivational if I get really specific feedback on something to fix than really generic positive feedback. At least in my experience, it's really rare to get very specific feedback, positive or negative, from a supervisor.

Hi, O:You certainly identified some key points from the reading that also resonated with me. For example that notion that the instructor needs to check in with students to determine what they are learning. When I thought about your post later on, however, I concluded that much of the ideas presented in the book are really common sense practices that instructors commonly adopt or should adopt. The structure of this course mirrors almost exactly many of the ideas presented in the book. Kukos to Instructor!One area that I struggle with in chapter 8 concerns collaboration. While in general I agree that collaboration is beneficial for all (students and instructor), I felt that the book did not address what happens when individual students have different learning objectives or career goals. And what about when students have different learning styles?

Hi Everyone,I'm in a coffee shop, so I am opting to write (both for privacy and bandwidth), but isn't this the fun of taking an online class -- you can do it in a coffee shop!Some highlights for me:I'm a big fan of "dialogue as inquiry" as stated on pages 170-171.  It reminds me of the purpose of social studies education (which I am studying).  Schools are perhaps the most democratic places students will find themselves in.  That is, outside of school students are often with like-minded people, either through their own friends, parents' friends, relatives, religious organizations etc.  It is in school that we need to develop their ability to dialogue with people unlike themselves.  In an online environment, as the authors suggest, this kind of dialogue is set up right away and it builds.  If the instructor provides "encouraging expansive questions" and steps back the students will take over the dialogue.  The authors use Brookfield and Preskill's findings (2005) stating as such, "the more successful students are at collaborating, the more they will seek it out" (p. 171).  In my experiences of both teaching online and f-2-f, it seems in the online environment this collaboration, while sometimes more difficult actually produces better results.  The process matters!Another highlight for me is "learning about technology by using it", pages 195-196.  Simply put, I want my mom and dad to take an online class!  They keep asking me questions about technology that are out of context and it's extremely frustrating.  I strongly believe that if they took an online class they would not only gain confidence in their technological skills, but recognize the power of technology to learn in ways that meets the needs of the adult learner.Connections/Disconnections among readings:This book must have been difficult to write.  I say this because everything is so connected.  Topics loop and loop again.  Transformative learning takes place through the collaborative process, right?  At least that's how I see it.  Through collaboration and learning about your own strengths and weaknesses of collaborating with others you can't help but transform.  You cannot help but reflect on how it is going and your own role and how you would do it better.  So, to me it's all one big string that is looping back on itself.Connections/Disconnections to other topics in class:I'm still a little caught up in communities of practice.  I think that they can be wonderful and amazing if everyone is committed to them.  Otherwise, it could simply be a bunch of people who happen to do the same thing and they talk about it sometimes.  This is where the reflection piece discussed in Chapter 9 becomes important.  I think I'd like to see more reflection both individuals and the group would be important in a community of practice.  Otherwise, the potential for growth as a community become limited.  Through reflection you get to see your strengths and areas for growth.Puzzle:As I read the text, it mirrors my experiences as an online instructor and as an online student.  That is, they really push for the instructor to set up the class for student interaction and if the instructor does it well, they can step out of the way.  OK, yes.  I have learned several things I will do next time I teach online - yippee!  However, I'm still left wondering what online learning looks like for a content specific class, such as biology or history, where they are taught in a traditional lecture style format.  I want to see what that looks like done well, following what the text says we ought to do.  Has anyone seen that? Experienced it? What was it like?

Hi G,I just had a moment to skim your article, but promise to really read it later b/c it definitely intrigues me. _To speak personally to your issue, I have taught a class called "Teaching in A Diverse Society" online and it was a bear of a class to teach. _As you indicate, the students were at all different levels of awareness on issues of power, racism, sexism, etc. that are required to teach in such a course. _I found that when I taught it online, but had the students in another class f-2-f they trusted me more and were more willing to take risks. _When I taught it exclusively online I had to really work to build trust, but ultimately many of the students saw me as "in their face" about these issues of diversity. _This is one reason I'm taking this course, should I ever teach the above mentioned course again I know I need to work on building more trust and community. On an interesting side note, I just so happened to have a conversation about this with a former colleague who is a woman of color. _Whenever she teaches this diversity class for pre-service teachers she prefers to teach it online. _She says often being the only person of color in the room and the person who has power as the teacher can be extremely uncomfortable for her and her students. _It's a power dynamic the students are not used to and when she presents such sensitive topics that you describe she knows her students hold back so as not to offend her. _Which, of course, is the opposite of what she wants - she wants them to ask questions and to make themselves vulnerable in their learning because ultimately she knows that these pre-service teachers will be working with students and families that are different from them.So, in the end I don't have an answer to your question because I think it's all contextual. _I do think this, however, no matter the format the instructor needs to find out what level of awareness the students are at and figure out ways to make space for them to blunder along the way so that they can move on the spectrum of awareness and action. _I also think we need to make space for K-12 educators to bring back the controversial issues so that by the time they come to college they are prepared to deal with differences in a variety of ways and to feel OK that there is never a "right" answer.

Identify 2 highlights from the readings. These could be quotes, ideas, or things you learned that resonated with you.I liked the idea of capturing "aha" moments through intentional reflection and creating space for it. I think that is why the blog for each of our online communities is working for me. It's allowing me to think about the past week and what I've noticed, how its helped me to be part of a conscious community, and where I have moved through and because of it. I also like the idea of it being part of a triple loop so that in the actual reflection we are also changing our assumptions. Earlier in our course the idea of the double loop came up on one of the discussion threads. These chapters helped me understand that concept better.What is 1 connection/disconnection among the readings?The other idea I related to in these chapters is the "disorienting dilemmas." _I would definitely say that a few times I have felt like I was back in 4th grade, my best friend just moved away, I was picked last for kick ball and I have no idea how to negotiate my next steps. I don't know that I would characterize some of my confusion in navigating online classes and the relationships I have developed through these classes as strongly as the reading -- psychic distortions seems a bit much to me...but definitely like I don't have all skills to work through the learning process sometimes.Considering our former class topics and readings, what is 1 connection/disconnection to CI 5323 overall?Again, I liked that these chapters brought the metacognitive piece into the online learning. With the community of inquiry and community of practice frameworks that piece does not seem to be explicitly discussed. I think it fits really nicely into the idea of a conscious community - if you are reflecting on your own learning you are better able to help others in the community with their learning and transformation.What is 1 question or puzzle that you still have regarding the readings?I think the challenge or puzzle in online courses would be to strike a balance between providing space for reflection and keeping mometum going. I'll confess that I have struggled in and out of yoga classes because sometimes feel like a caged bird in the Shavasana at the end of the class. I would think that too much reflection space can slow down the learning as well.

2 Highlights from the reading:I have really enjoyed this book and often find it hard to pick out pieces because I have so many- _In chapter 8 one of the quotes that jumped out to me was on page 158 "The online environment can be a lonely place. Students and faculty alike report feelings of isolation when working online." _I would strongly agree with this statement. _Online learning is a process that you need to responsible for your own learning and be motivated to stay on-task and keep up with the course work. You do not have that weekly physical check in of a class or instructor. _At the beginning I found this isolation to be more of a problem than I do today as I have adjusted to the style. Chapter 9 really talked about the reflection and on page 186 stated "Another parallel process should be self-refection. _Participants should ask themselves, "How am I growing and changing as a learner and as a person through all of these interactions?" _Self reflection has been a big piece of many of my classes and through this my reflection skills have been strengthen in many ways. _Self reflection is not always an easy or fun process, yet the importance is large. _It gives you the chance to see of the material is growing and changing and how the connections are coming together.One Connection in the reading:The idea of transformational learning was discussed on page 187. Mezirow (1990) states that perspectives are transformed when learners encounter what her terms disorienting dilemmas" _It goes on to say that "online classroom is fertile territory for transformative learning." To me this statement is also connecting to the importance of reflection and looking at how the material is connecting and what questions do I still have and in what ways has my learning changed. __Reflection often causes us to encounter disorienting dilemmas as we think about new material and read others ideas.I feel that all the material from the past topics and reading continues to build upon each other. _We are continuing to hear about the importance of social presence and reflection. _I really have enjoyed how they continue to make connections- this has allowed for me deeper learning to take place. Questions :I do not have any questions- _My only thought is how helpful this class has been to really learning and understanding online classes. _I teach in parent education and I do believe that online parenting classes is something that we will see more and more of in the future. _As parents continue to get busier and busier online classes are going to be a way to share information, have questions answered and new connection made.

In page 158, Jonassen and others note that the collaborative in a constructivist classroom results not only in personal meaning-making on the part of the individual student, but also creates a container wherein social construction of knowledge and meaning can occur. Hi R,The difference between a self-evaluation and a team-evaluation is that you are only evaluating yourself in the former. The self-evaluation gives you a chance to reflect on your effort and provides the instructor with an idea of how you feel you performed. On the other hand, a team-evaluation gives all members of the team an opportunity to assess your performance. Often times, team members' ratings are averaged. When this feedback is shared with the instructor, it allows the instructor to gain better insight on how the team worked together. If all of the team members have good things to say about each other, we assume they worked well together. If all the team members identify a single person as a "slacker," this is also noteworthy. One thing that should always be considered, however, is that sometimes team members don't say anything negative because they fear that this may affect their grade or that others may not share the same feelings and they don't want to put an unnecessary light on themselves. I hope this helps answer your question!

Highlights. One of the simple ideas that I really like is that shared goals are a critical component of developing an effective community. One of the reasons I find academic communities to be much more effective than non-academic communities is that instructors and students naturally work toward clear goals that are tied to learning and completing the course. When utilizing a non-academic community, members may not necessarily be working toward common goals. They may be searching for advice or support but what they do with that information and, ultimately, their end-goal may not be the same. Connections. Chapter 9 discusses learning about technology by using it. This jumped out at me right away because that is exactly the feeling I've had during this course, thus far. I have learned about a number of new technologies and it wasn't until I actually used the technology (e.g., VoiceThread, Flipgrid) that I saw it's true value and could appreciate the medium. I believe this also means that there is some pressure on instructors to utilize the best types of technology, as well as a wide variety of technologies to allow students to gain exposure and promote learning.I thought the example of the female student who disappeared for awhile after her introduction was interesting, too. I believe we have come across this example before. I think this is definitely noteworthy because it demonstrates expectations and the impact not meeting those expectations has on people. This example reminds me a little bit of Facebook and how people often post status updates or photos and truly measure how many friends they have by the number of "likes" or responses. I think this is potentially destructive but, no doubt, plays a huge role in online communities. I suppose the takeaway is that we need to manage our expectations, as well as communicate clearly, and we shouldn't measure our worth by the feedback. Additionally, this relates to the point I made in the beginning of the semester where we should try to view others in a positive light, as opposed to negatively. We shouldn't assume non-responses mean that people don't care but rather they didn't know they were supposed to respond or got really busy. Question. Hi H, I so appreciate your comments on the need to teach collaboration. _I often think, especially for adult learners, we can forget that not all people are good at this or even have practice doing it. _We definitely cannot assume. _It makes me think about K-12 education and how little we allow our students to collaborate. Then if students spend their undergraduate career in large lecture courses, they continue to get little practice. _It's no wonder that as adult learners they may feel uncomfortable or don't know how exactly to do it. _So...I like your comment on the need to explicitly teach it or clearly explain the expectations. I'm also a fan of Johnson & Johnson's PIGS FACE when they talk about collaborative learning (they are mentioned several times in the text). _I'm a big fan of "G" which stands for group processing. _This allows the group time to reflect on how they did as a group - what went well, what needs work. _Unless you spend the time doing this you cannot get better!

Identify 2 highlights from the readings. These could be quotes, ideas, or things you learned that resonated with you.P. 167 _ Problems, Interests, and Experiences As Spring Boards for Learning.The more participants can relate their life experiences and what they already know to the context of the online classroom, the deeper their understanding will be of what they learn.Life experience is something I feel very strongly about when it comes to teaching. I dont think I was particularly ready to student teach or overly confident in my first few years of teaching, but the support of my colleagues and being confronted with unique situations every day has given me quite a collection of stories and material on which to reflect and learn from. I am on year 8 right now in my current position and although I feel like I am more than prepared to handle the content side of my job, the teaching aspect is something I am constantly reflecting, adjusting, tweaking, and revising as standards, teacher evaluations, students, and administration change from year to year. I have really enjoyed the opportunity to bring in my experiences from my classroom along with the opportunities to reflect on my current practice whether it is online or f2f. Although I am not currently facilitating any online courses, the knowledge I am gaining and combining with my current instruction is creating some excitement for the future and what direction I see my classes headed in.P.187 _ Mezirow (1990) states that perspectives are transformed when learners encounter what he terms disorienting dilemmas _ dilemmas that cause the learner to critically assess distortions in the areas of the nature and use of knowledge, belief systems related to power and social relationships, and psychic distortions _ or presuppositions that cause anxiety and inaction.This statement holds a great deal of truth for myself, as this is my first true online course. As much as I thought I was prepared for learning in this manner, there was a great deal of anxiety on my part as we began our journey into online learning communities. I am not a very organized person outside of those things I can feel direct control over and the openness of the course freaked me out the most. I completed my first online course (Research Methods from UW-RF) in the fall and it was nothing like this one. The instructor was the only person I dealt with and never communicated with my peers. As I work my way through this class, I find myself constantly reflecting on how I view the delivery of knowledge and the use of online communities. It has given me so much more to think about, much of which I was not aware of its existence. My perspective has definitely changed to be more open to how knowledge is acquired and how in so many ways online courses are more beneficial for some types of learners.What is 1 connection/disconnection among the readings?I see feedback and reflection being connected topics that most interest me in these two readings. When considering the most important factors in building relationships and in turn creating beneficial collaborative opportunities, trust has to be paramount.As we give feedback and read comments from our peers, the gears begin to move. We examine where we are in the world and our beliefs on whatever the topic may be and evaluate whether there is room for change or adjustment. Feedback drives our reflection and the ways in which our classmates challenge our ideas, thoughts, and comments. Considering our former class topics and readings, what is 1 connection/disconnection to CI 5323 overall or prior readings?These two chapters have really helped cement the foundation of building successful online communities and the looping within all these interconnected topics becomes clearer.All this information seems to come back on how building an online presence is heavily reliant on positive interactions through personal introductions, student communication, facilitator interaction or lack there of, and building confidence in navigating the software while developing an identity in a digital world.What is 1 question or puzzle that you still have regarding the readings? Much of this information isnt always age specific, I get the feeling that much of this research and case studies come from adult learners and graduate students. The constant question in the back of my mind remains whether I can develop a similar approach to use with my high school students. I feel an obligation to prepare them for this changing educational paradigm, but struggle with my observations of their maturity and ability to process something complex like the transformative learning framework.

Highlights:One quote that really resonated with me is found on pg.171; "Brookfeld and Preskill (2005) state that collaboration can become addictive: the more successful students are at collaborating, the more they will seek it out. Therefore, promoting good, collaborative discussion can assist them in developing an appreciation for other forms of collaborative work." After reading this, I had a "hmmm" moment as it really made me think about my experiences in collaborating with other students, both in class, and other online and f2f classes I've taken in the past. Does collaboration really become addictive for me? I don't necessarily agree, but I do agree that good collaborative discussions assist in developing an appreciation for other forms of collaborative work. I also appreciated the quote on pg. 179 from Stephen Covey (1989), discussing the ability to "seek first to understand, then be understood." This further defines the importance of interdependence and the need for each online learner to gravitate towards interdependence to have more meaningful collaborative discussions. What is 1 connection/disconnection among the readings? The strongest connection among the two chapters for me was its ability to tie collaboration to transformational learning. I see a strong connection between integrating collaboration into an online learning environment and then being able to create a transformational experience for the student. Even though transformational experiences are usually unconsciously driven, it's imperative to integrate collaborative learning exercises and activities into an online course, so those transformational experiences come to light. I felt these two chapters connected with each other really well and helped me to understand how to build collaboration and transformation together within a course. Considering our former class topics and readings, what is 1 connection/disconnection to CI 5323 overall or prior readings? All of our previous readings and class topics integrate so well into the overarching theme of "Online Learning Communities." What is 1 question or puzzle that you still have regarding the readings? I'd like to further investigate how f2f environments differ with online environments as they relate to transformational learning. I don't necessarily agree with the statements on pg. 191, that reflection isn't encouraged in f2f classrooms. It all goes back to the instructor and what their definition of reflection means and how they integrate self-reflection into their environment, as well as how they ask students to apply meaning to their own lives.

One of the things that I hadn't given much thought to previously was the importance of not only having students introduce themselves to each other in the first week of an online course, but that it is important for each new member to acknowledge the other individuals in their class, in return. This 2-way dynamic may not be necessary between all members of the class, but it sure helps members find common ground and a sense of being a valued member of the community.A second realization I came to in the readings was the idea that, with "the additional component of letting students share resources...a greatly expanded bibliography of readings can be developed to allow students to explore far beyond the confines of the readings assigned for the course." (Ch. 8, P. 181) This is what I find so fascinating about this form of instruction, its collaborative nature and thereby, its expansiveness. With this comes the challenge of reigning it in, at times; to stay on task when you're curiosity wants to take you in yet another direction.In our Oliver, Harrington, Harrington & Reeves article, the authors make the distinction within group work between simple cooperation in the division of roles and responsibilities, and collaboration, which affords more opportunities for learning through increased knowledge generation and improved problem solving. In this way, the group can accomplish more than any one individual. "Well-designed collaborative learning activities capture the dynamic of real world complexity." (Oliver, Harrington, Harrington & Reeves, p. 2). Our book goes a bit further with this idea on P. 157 where it discusses Johnson & Johnson's (2005) "positive group interdependence", referring to the sink or swim together dynamic which most of us live in our daily work and personal lives.Finally, one area of uncertainty I have relates to how team members evaluate each others' performance. Although I've read studies showing that this type of peer review performs as well as instructor evaluations, I have a hard time believing this. The book's discussion of this issue on P. 166 includes the possibility of this practice setting up a sense of competition between members, rather than cooperation, within the group. However, I do believe team self-evaluation can encourage members to join a higher-functioning team, as mentioned on P. 167, as everyone wants to be part of a winning team ;)
